content: Over on the “Religion in the Military” is a related thread dealing with quote: [….if the DA/DT] …ban is lifted. In the years since Don't Ask, Don't Tell was adopted in 1993, there has been a rigorous effort to force religion into the barracks. Fundamentalist Christian groups have infiltrated some of our leading military bases and have made life uncomfortable for anyone who does not conform. Sadly, the proselytizing continues with powerful military leaders behaving more like missionaries, than soldiers entrusted with fulfilling military missions. ….the purpose of these groups is to turn religion from a private, individual matter into a coercive team sport. As we contemplate the battle over allowing openly gay people in the military, we should also consider what type of military they would serve in. As a nation, we must ensure that the military's number one priority is preparing for war, not worship. If we don't grapple with this issue, Don't Ask, Don't Tell may become, Do Tell, Live In Hell for gay and lesbian service members brave enough to come out. http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/127003199...812001#9370090812001

content: I posted this in "point counterpoint" and I think it relates to what you have posted. You have to go to the link and read the full article to understand what he is saying. I think it is one of the best Op-Ed articles I have read in a long time. The Culture Warriors Get Laid Off SOMEDAY we’ll learn the whole story of why George W. Bush brushed off that intelligence briefing of Aug. 6, 2001, “Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S.” But surely a big distraction was the major speech he was readying for delivery on Aug. 9, his first prime-time address to the nation. The subject — which Bush hyped as “one of the most profound of our time” — was stem cells. For a presidency in thrall to a thriving religious right (and a presidency incapable of multi-tasking), nothing, not even terrorism, could be more urgent. When Barack Obama ended the Bush stem-cell policy last week, there were no such overheated theatrics. No oversold prime-time address. No hysteria from politicians, the news media or the public. The family-values dinosaurs that once stalked the earth — Falwell, Robertson, Dobson and Reed — are now either dead, retired or disgraced. Their less-famous successors pumped out their pro forma e-mail blasts, but to little avail. The Republican National Committee said nothing whatsoever about Obama’s reversal of Bush stem-cell policy. That’s quite a contrast to 2006, when the party’s wild and crazy (and perhaps transitory) new chairman, Michael Steele, likened embryonic stem-cell research to Nazi medical experiments during his failed Senate campaign. Read the full article here > >http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/15/opinion/15rich.html?_r=2&ref=opinion

content: quote: Huffington Post is one of those places where it's all opinion and very little fact. But, this piece did actually pull in some "religion in the Military" type news and I thought it would be useful on a group so named. Let's make sure to add the poster's opinion of the source he took it from. I read the article over in the "Religion Atheism in the Military" forum, and found it to be the biggest load of hypocritical crap I have ever seen, and I am being nice when I say that. I don't know whether to be amused, ****ed off, or just dumbfounded at the idiotic, misleading "facts" that this article tries to represent, or the agenda that the people that reiterate such garbage attend to push with it. Homosexuals want to take some of the extreme Christians in the military and try to compare it to the group as a whole. Hmm, this seems very familiar. Oh yeah, it's the same kind of crap that gays say straights do to them. Homosexuals have their special "homosexuals in the military" groups that proselytize everyone and calls people that don't convert to their way of thinking things like homophobe, and the like, yet apparently in their eyes they are the only ones who should be afforded the rights to do this. So first they want to repeal DADT, then destroy spiritual moral and readiness which is sometimes the only thing that helps these soldiers to go into battle. Should we get rid of the church services in the chapel that take place on base too? Let's destroy the way of living for millions in order to appease thousands. The people who wrote that article are hypocrites that care only for themselves with no perception of service before self.
